div.head: To make a Tart of Medlers.
div.p: Take Medlers that be rotten, and ſtamp them, and ſet them upon a chafingdiſh with coales, and beat in two yolks of Eggs, boyling till it be ſomewhat thick, then ſeaſon it with Sugar, Cinamon, and Ginger, and lay it in paſte.

div.head: Of Cucumbers.
How to keep Cucumbers.
div.p:
Take a kettle big enough for your uſe, halfe full of water, make
it brackiſh with ſalt, boyle therein ten or twenty Cucumbers,, cut in halves, then take the raw Cucumbers, being ſomewhat little, and put them into the veſſell wherein you will keep them, and when your liquor is cold ſtraine ſo much of it into them, as may keep the Cucumbers alwayes covered.

div.head: To keep boyled Cucumbers.
div.p: Take a kettle of water, put ſalt to it, boyle it well, then take your raw Cucumbers, put them into it, and keep them with turning up and downe very ſoftly, till they be as it were per-boyled, then take them out, and lay them aſide till they be cold, then put them up in the veſſel you will keep them in, and when the liquor is cold, ſtraine it into them, till they be all covered.

div.head: To Pickle Cucumbers to keep all the yeare.
div.p: Pare a good quantity of the rindes of Cucumbers, and boyle them in a quart of running water, and a pint of wine Vineger, with a handfull of ſalt, till they be ſoft, then letting them ſtand till the liquor be quite cold, pour out the liquor from the rinds, into ſome little barrell, earthen pot, or other veſſel, that may be cloſe ſtopped, and put as many of the youngeſt Cucumbers you can gather, therein, as the liquor will cover, and ſo keep them cloſe covered, that no winde come to them, to uſe all the year till they have new; if your Cucumbers be great, 'tis beſt to boyle them in the liquor till they be ſoft.

div.head: OF COOKERY.
To make Snow.
div.p:
Take a quart of thick Creame, and five or ſix whites of Eggs, a ſauſer full of ſugar finely beaten, and as much Roſe water, beat them all together, and always as it riſeth take it out with a ſpoon,
then take a loaf of Bread, cut away the cruſt, ſet it in a platter, and a great Roſemary buſh in the middeſt of it, then lay your Snow with a Spoon upon the Roſemary, and ſo ſerve it.

div.head: To make Spiced Bread.
div.p: Take two pound of Manchet paſte, ſweet Butter halfe a pound, Currants halfe a pound, ſugar a quarter, and a little Mace, if you will put in any, and make it in a loafe, and bake it in an Oven, no hotter then for Manchet.

div.head: To make Craknels.
div.p: Take five or fix pints of the fineſt Wheat flower you can get, to which you muſt put in a ſpoonfull (and not above) of good Yeſt, then mingle it well with Butter, cream, Roſe-water, and ſugar, finely beaten, and working it well into paſte, make it after what forme you will, and bake it.

div.head: To make Veale-tooh's, or Olives.
div.p: Take the Kidney of a line of Veale roaſted, with a good deale of the far, and a little of the fleſh, mingle it very ſmall, and put to it two Eggs, one Nutmeg finely grated, a good quantity of ſugar, a few Currants, a little ſalt, ſtir them well together, and make them into the form of little Paſties, and fry them in a pan with ſweet Butter.

div.head: To make a Barley Creame to procure ſleepe, or Almond Milke.
div.p:
Take a good handfull of French Barley, waſh it cleane in warme water, and boyle it in a quart of fayre water to the halfe, then put out the water from the Barley, and put the Barley into a pottell of new clean water, with a Parſley, and a Fennell root, clean waſhed, and picked with Bourage, Buglos, Violet leaves, and Lettice, of each one handfull, boyle them with the Barley, till more then halfe be conſumed; then ſtrayne out the liquor, and take of blanched Almonds a handfull, of the ſeeds of Melons, Cucumbers, Citralls; and Gourds, husked, of each halfe a quarter of an ounce, beat theſe ſeeds, and the Almonds together, in a ſtone morter, with ſo much
Sugar, and Roſe-water as is fit, and ſtrayne them through a cleane cloach into the liquor, and drink thereof at night going to bed, and in the night, if this doth not ſufficiently provoke ſleep, then make ſome more of the ſame liquor, and boyle in the ſame the heads, or a little of white Poppey.

div.head: To pickle Oyſters.
div.p: Take a peck of the greateſt Oyſters; open them, and put the liquor that comes from them ſaved by it ſelfe, to as much White-wine, and boyle it with a pound of Pepper bruiſed, two or three ſpoonfulls of large Mace, and a handfull of ſalt, till the liquor begin to waſte away; then put in your Oyſters, and plump them, and take them off the fire till they be cold, and ſo put them up in little barrels very cloſe.

div.head: To make very fine Sauſages.
div.p: Take four pound and a halfe of Porck, chop it ſmall, and put to it three pound of Beefe ſewet, and chop them ſmall together, then put to them a handfull of Sage, finely ſhred, one ounce of Pepper, one ounce of Mace, two ounces of Cloves, a good deale of ſalt, eight Eggs very well beaten before you put them in, then work them well with your hand, till they be throughly mingled, and then fill them up. Some like not the Eggs in them, it is not amiſſe therefore to leave them out.

div.head: To caſt all kind of Sugar works into Moulds.
div.p: Take one pound of Barabry Sugar, Clarifie it with the white of an Egg, boyle it till it will roule between your finger and your thumb, then caſt it into your ſtanding Moulds, being watered two hours before in cold water, take it out and gild them to garniſh a Marchpine with them at your pleaſure.

div.head: To make all kinde of turned works in fruitage, hollow.
div.p:
Take the ſtrongeſt bodyed Sugar you can get, boyle it to the height of Manus Chriſti, take your ſtone, or rather pewter moulds, being made in three pieces, tye the two great pieces together with Inkle, then poure in your Sugar being highly boyled, turne
it round about your head apace, and ſo your fruitage will be hol
• ow, whether it be Orange, or Lemmon, or whatſoever your Mould doth caſt, after they be caſt you muſt colour them after their natudall colours.

div.head: To make a Sallet of all kinde of Hearbs.
div.p: Take your Hearbs and pick them very fine in faire water, and pick your Flowers by themſelves, and waſh them clean, then ſwing them in a ſtrayner, and when you put them into a diſh mingle them with Cucumbers or Lemmons pared and ſliced, alſo ſcrape ſugar, and put in Vineger and Oyle, then ſpread the Flowers on the top of the ſallet, and with every ſort of the aforeſaid things garniſh the diſh about, then take Eggs boyled hard, and lay about the diſh and upon the Sallet.

div.head: To make Fritter-ſtuffe.
div.p: Take fine flower, and three or four Eggs, and put into the flower, and a piece of Butter, and let them boyle all together in a diſh or chaffer, and put in ſugar, cinamon, ginger, and roſe water, and in the boyling put in a little grated Bread, to make it big, then put it into a diſh, and beat it well together, and ſo put it into your mould, and fly it with clarified Butter, but your Butter may not be too hot, nor too cold.
